title.value: Meta-Graph: Few Shot Link Prediction via Meta Learning
title.justification: This title captures the essence of the paper's focus on few-shot link prediction using a meta-learning framework called Meta-Graph.
title.quote: We introduce a new framework called Meta-Graph for few shot link prediction and also introduce a series of benchmarks for this task.

extractions.description: The paper addresses the problem of few shot link prediction across multiple graphs with sparse data. To tackle this, it introduces Meta-Graph, a gradient-based meta-learning framework that leverages higher-order gradients and a learned graph signature function for generating graph neural network initializations.

type.justification: The paper presents experimental results on three benchmarks to validate the performance of Meta-Graph in comparison to other baseline methods.
type.quote: We experimentally validate our approach on three link prediction benchmarks.

name.justification: The paper employs deep learning techniques, specifically graph neural networks, and focuses on improving their performance through meta-learning.
name.quote: ...we deploy this strategy to train graph neural networks (GNNs) that are capable of few-shot link prediction.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on using graph neural networks to solve the problem of few-shot link prediction.
name.quote: ...we introduce a graph signature function, which learns how to map the structure of an input graph to an effective initialization point for a GNN link prediction model.

name.justification: The Meta-Graph model is the primary contribution of the paper, aimed at solving the few-shot link prediction task.
name.quote: We introduce a new framework called Meta-Graph for few shot link prediction...

name.justification: The Variational Graph Autoencoder is used as the base model within the Meta-Graph framework.
name.quote: In principle, our framework can be combined with a wide variety of GNN-based link prediction approaches, but here we focus on variational graph autoencoders (VGAEs) (Kipf & Welling, 2016b) as our base link prediction framework.

name.justification: The Protein-Protein Interaction (PPI) dataset is used as one of the benchmarks to validate the Meta-Graph framework.
name.quote: Two of our benchmarks are derived from standard multi-graph datasets from protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks (Zitnik & Leskovec, 2017) and 3D point cloud data (FirstMMDB).

name.justification: The FirstMM-DB dataset is used as another benchmark to validate the Meta-Graph framework.
name.quote: Two of our benchmarks are derived from standard multi-graph datasets from protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks (Zitnik & Leskovec, 2017) and 3D point cloud data (FirstMMDB).

name.justification: The Ego-AMiner dataset is created and used as a novel benchmark for evaluating the Meta-Graph framework.
name.quote: We also create a novel multi-graph dataset based upon the AMINER citation data (Tang et al., 2008), where each node corresponds to a paper and links represent citations.

name.justification: The Bayesian Optimization Library is employed for hyperparameter selection in the Meta-Graph framework.
name.quote: For Meta-Graph and all of these baselines we employ Bayesian optimization with Thompson sampling (Kandasamy et al., 2018) to perform hyperparameter selection using the validation sets.
